content.question: Figure 1. A simplified model of a <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></math> replication fork Which of the following statements best explains the role of Enzyme 1 in the <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> replication process?

choices.label: Enzyme 1 is a <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> ligase that joins together the <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> fragments at a replication fork to form continuous strands.

Enzyme 1 is a <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> primase that catalyzes the synthesis of <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> primers on the lagging strand of a replication fork.

Enzyme 1 is a <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> polymerase that synthesizes new <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> by using the leading and lagging strands of a replication fork as templates.
Enzyme 1 is a topoisomerase that relieves tension in the overwound <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in front of a replication fork.

content.answer: Enzyme 1 is a topoisomerase that relieves tension in the overwound <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in front of a replication fork.
